On Sat, Oct 11, 2008 at 3:14 PM, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> I understand that "hierarchical, modular, and formalized" are
> sometimes viewed as advantages for Grammatical Encoding (a similar
> argument is also made for L-systems, which is also grammatical).
> While these are clearly properties you want in a programming language,
> are these really good things for a genetic encoding? The challenge
> with encodings is not only for them to theoretically express all
> possible procedures, but also to induce a nicely coupled (smooth)
> search space. It seems that the space induced by a strictly modular
> and hierarchical encodings is unlikely to be smooth, leading to
> brittleness. You can have things like a massive new module being
> doubled in one shot (which would usually be a mess, like being born
> with two heads) or a change at one level of the hierarchy breaking the
> rest of it entirely.

And yet if evolution stumbles upon a module whose usefulness stems
from multiple occurrences, how else would this be accomplished? If we
want artificial encodings to be able to produce something like a
mammalian brain, aren't they necessarily going to incorporate
hierarchy and modularity?

--Derek
